div1.head: Newspaper clipping, The Washington Post, [February 23, 1901]
div1.p:
We have not the slightest doubt that
Senor Cisneros, when he threatened the
United States with war, on Thursday last,
spoke for an overwhelming majority of
the Cuban convention which he was then
addressing. The only difference between
Cisneros and the horde of professional
outlaws our authorities have been petting
and coddling for the past two years is
that he reveals his purpose, while they
nurse it in malignant silence. We think
now, as we have always thought, that our
government has managed the Cuban sit-
uation with almost inspired fatuity. We
believe, as we have always believed, that
in giving power, place, and emolument to
the incendiary leaders and ignoring the
representatives of property, culture, and
conservatism we have made impossible a
peaceful solution of the Cuban imbroglio
or a satisfactory fulfillment of whatever
promise may have been contained in the
Teller amendment to the war resolutions
of 1898.

Senor Cisneros, we may say, is entitled
to far more respect now than at any time
in his history. When he was darting
about from one refuge to another in the
Cuban hills, and carrying with him the
whole of the alleged “civil government”
of the patriots on a single mule, he made
no appeal to the recognition of intelligent
men. On the contrary, he presented a
spectacle of ragamuffin absurdity which
almost moved one to tears. But now,
when he takes his courage in both hands
and proclaims to the world his hatred of
“the intervening power” and his fixed de-
termination to resist its encroachments to
the bitter end, he is at least the figure of
a brave and candid man. We know upon
overwhelming testimony that what he
says is what nine-tenths of his fellow-
agitators feel, and we see in him a person
who dares to speak his mind.

It is fortunate that the President means
to assemble Congress in extra session at
an early date. He has borne the respon-
sibility of this wretched Cuban business
long enough. No doubt he has acted in a
spirit of sincere humanity and patriotism,
but in one way or another things have
gone wrong from the first, and are get-
ting to be more and more perilous and
complicated every day. It is high time
that Congress should assume the task of
interpreting its own pledges and realizing
its own theories. Far too much has been
made of the Teller resolution. It contains
a promise, perhaps, and therefore should
be taken into serious account. But there
are higher and more sacred obligations
which must be discharged before that
promise can be considered. No matter
how anxious we may be to dismiss Cuba
to its destiny and wash our hands of it,
there are other duties to ourselves and to
the civilized world which have a prior
claim. If we promised Cuba independence
and self-government, we also promised
Cuba's inhabitants peace, order, and se-
curity, and made ourselves responsible to
the powers for that consummation. Those
powers stood aside, postponing the asser-
tion of their interests and trusting us to
protect and guarantee them. We are
bound to make sure of this before we
withdraw from the island and leave it to
the mercies and devices of its direst ene-
mies.

Let us have a definite settlement of
these questions by all means. To with-
draw from Cuba before its enlightened
government is assured would be far more
dishonorable than to seize it outright and
finally remove the problem from the arena
of discussion.
